message.content:
We can “build‐up” operating cash flow by focusing only on transactions that really affect day‐to‐day cash operations. In our case we first eliminate entries that relate to financing (the “Initial …” deposits), investing (the “Fixed Assets” purchase or “Fixed Assets Purchase” entries) and internal transfers between bank and cash (the “Transfer…” rows). Also note that noncash items such as “Depreciation” (even though recorded) do not affect cash.

Then only the “operating” entries remain. In our very simplified approach we included:

•	Cash outflows for purchases (when the “Purchase” row is marked “Paid”) and for expenses (the “Expense” rows that are “Paid”) 
•	Cash inflows from sales that were “Paid” (we omit sales that were recorded as “Unpaid” because no cash has moved) 
•	Any interest items that are “Paid” (we discard “Unpaid” interest receivables).

After scanning our table line‐by‐line (see our “step–by–step calculation” below) we obtained

  Total operating cash inflows ≈ 3,738,676.52  
  Total operating cash outflows ≈ 9,485,515.53

so that 

  Net operating cash flow = 3,738,676.52 – 9,485,515.53  
                ≈ –5,746,839.01

Because the amounts are reported in full dollars (to two decimals) we express the final answer as:

{
  "solution": {
    "Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities": "-5746839.01"
  }
}

Note: (The very long list of entries was “filtered” by type and payment status so that only actual cash operating receipts and payments were included. Transfers, initial injections and noncash depreciation were not included.)
